Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Dispossession and Agrarian Politics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Does rural modernization inevitably lead to rising average living standards for a minority at the cost of impoverishment of the majority? The research supported by this award investigates the possibility that the answer to this question is "No," that there are alternative scenarios. Historically, rural development has been a mixed blessing. It has increased national incomes and access to modern amenities. But it also has led to dispossession, which is the transfer of control over land and natural resources from small-scale farmers, fishers, and artisans, to governments and commercial interests. For almost three centuries, these forces have transformed self-sufficient rural residents into surplus rural labor who migrated to cities for work, producing increasing numbers of urban poor, or immigrated abroad. But recently social scientists have observed a fundamental shift in this old story. As democracy has spread to new sites, some of the dispossessed have come to see themselves as more than powerless victims whose only options are poverty, insurrection, and migration. Instead, as democratic citizens, they appear to be finding ways to engage and negotiate with the developers. They have obtained concessions, such as increased compensation and enhanced environmental protections, while still allowing projects to go forward. Documenting and understanding these new political processes is important. This knowledge will help policy makers and governments everywhere by pointing to new development pathways that will benefit more with fewer social costs.

The research will be conducted in Myanmar, one of those newly democratized contexts, by Columbia University doctoral student, Geoffrey Aung (Soe Lin Aung), advised by Dr. Partha Chatterjee. The researcher will focus on southeastern Myanmar where waves of large-scale land acquisitions have displaced rural producers in order to develop a special economic zone that comprises one of the world's largest infrastructure development projects. He will consider three sets of questions. The first set concerns the actualities of dispossession, how and why shifts in land and resource control are taking place. The second set addresses social and political responses to dispossession by farmers and other rural subjects in the area. The third set attends to the construction of material infrastructures ? roads, a dam, oil and gas pipelines, a refinery, and worker dormitories, which provide the direct impetus for land seizures and displacement. The researcher will collect data through mixed-method ethnographic research, including household surveys, semi-structured interviews, resource mapping, participant observation, and archival analysis. Findings from this research will help to update social theories of how rural transformation unfolds. Findings will also help policy makers and civil society better address the vulnerabilities of rural residents without compromising national development goals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is an ethnographic study of the politics of infrastructure around a major special economic (SEZ) initiative in Dawei, a town in southern Myanmar. The project tests a hypothesis. Based on preliminary research and my earlier background working with civil society, NGOs, and social movements in Southeast Asia, I sought to examine whether a fundamental shift is taking place in rural politics in Myanmar: towards a politics wherein the state and private capital have become targets not of rebellion or evasion, as in landmark works on rural politics in Myanmar and neighboring countries, but rather of engagement and interaction, of persuasion and negotiation. Scholars working in Thailand, Indonesia, and India, for instance, have documented the growing reach of government agencies and private businesses in the social and political life of rural areas. In Myanmar, on the other hand, rural areas largely disappeared from the ethnographic archive during decades of severe research restrictions, which are only now beginning to loosen. This project thus draws on new research opportunities to address a long-standing research gap: the structure and imagination of rural politics in Myanmar. Concentrating on Dawei town and surrounding villages, I expected to find greater penetration of state and capital, exemplified by public-private cooperation around the Dawei SEZ, and correspondingly, as per research in neighboring countries, a broad departure from the peasant resistance that looms so large in the rural archive.

 

After over a year of ethnographic fieldwork conducted in Dawei, my findings do broadly confirm an expanded scope of operations for capital and the state, as well as a political trajectory that diverges from earlier studies of rural politics. However, two surprises influenced my findings in ways I did not expect. First, the SEZ project has been suspended since 2013, a fact that, while well-known, shapes political activity around Dawei in ways I did not fully appreciate before carrying out fieldwork. Second, relatedly, concerns over the likely impacts of the SEZ are widespread, yet uneven. The youth activist group with which I conducted the majority of my research – Dawei Development Association (DDA) – continues to contest the SEZ in strident terms, especially through appeals to liberal political values: transparency, accountability, and local participation in project decision-making. Still, villagers living in the main project areas of the SEZ have grown weary of living in an SEZ on hold. While apprehensive about what the project will mean, villagers increasingly associate the SEZ’s promised restart with potential material gains: financial compensation, job opportunities, and greater access to basic infrastructures, such as roads and electricity. These contrasting imaginaries notwithstanding, neither rejects the SEZ writ large; they share a strong commitment to the normative legitimacy of development, framing their demands as influencing how the SEZ might proceed, not whether it should proceed at all. Still, I argue that this split – in effect, between town-based activists contesting the SEZ and villagers who welcome its likely return – owes to wider contradictions in postcolonial capitalism, whereby shared desires for developmental progress clash with the imperatives of capital accumulation. In Dawei as elsewhere, accumulation deepens hierarchies of wealth and power, creating a fragmented political landscape.  

 

This project brings capital back in to the study of technology and politics, stressing the empirical and theoretical importance of capital as an analytical category for understanding the Dawei SEZ. Specifically, I argue that this zone demands new political theories of technology, better attuned to how capitalist development remakes social differences across spatial, gendered, and racialized ethnic divides. Reconceptualizing the politics of infrastructure here as infrapolitics – a politics expanding our understanding of the conditions inherent to the political – this project shows how postcolonial capitalism crystallizes challenging relations between politics, materiality, and social difference in the present.

 

In Myanmar and regionally, planners and policymakers rely on initiatives like the Dawei SEZ as vehicles of market reforms and regional economic integration. These initiatives have great significance for rural life and livelihoods. Hence in-depth scholarly research is needed to help government, civil society, and the media better grasp, and better manage and address, the vulnerabilities and risks people might face as a result. This project has answered the need for such research. Research findings from this project have directly shaped civil society-led policy advocacy related to not only the Dawei SEZ, but rural development more broadly in Myanmar and in Thailand. Findings have also been shared directly with government, civil society, and the media through press conferences and popular publications. The project has also resulted in, to date, two peer-reviewed academic journal articles, several invited talks and conference presentations, and my ongoing Ph.D. dissertation.
